knowledge and providers (Ockwell and Byrne 2016), negative impacts in terms of higher costs
, and balance of payments constraints and vulnerability to
The climate technology transition can also yield other development benefits, for instance better health,
increased energy access, poverty alleviation and economic competitiveness
including industrial development, job creation and economic growth

growing complexity of technologies and global competition have made the development of a
technology into a globalized process involving the flow of knowledge and products ac
. For instance, in production of electronics, Asian economies
location synergies and dominate production and assembly of product components,
renewable energy technologies, “green global division of labour” has been observed, with countries
specialising in investments in R&D, manufacturing or deployment of renewables
In the case of solar PV, for example, while many of the technical innovations emerged from the
US, Japan and China emphasized the manufacture of physical modules
Such globalization of production and supply chains open
s up economic development opportunities for
. At the same time, not all countries benefit from the
globalisation of innovation, as barriers remain related to finance, environmental performance, human
particularly disadvantaged at leveraging these opportunities. The gap in low
innovation between countries appears to have been reducing only amongst OECD countries

to 70 years, even within one country, and recommend that innovation efforts be balanced
between on the one hand commercialising already low
phase, and diffusing them globally, and on the other hand early
Thus international cooperation on technology development and transfer can enable developing
countries to achieve their climate g
oals more effectively, while also addressing other sustainable
development goals, taking advantage, where possible, of the globalization of innovation and production
. Earlier assessments in the AR5 and SR1.5 have made it clear that international
technology transfer and cooperation could play a role in c
limate policy at both the international and the
018b; Stavins et al. 2014; Somanathan et al. 2014)
. The Paris Agreement also reflects this view
by noting that countries shall strengthen cooperative action on technology development and transfer
regarding two main aspects: 1) promoting collaborative approaches to research and de
2) facilitating access to technology to developing country Parties
